metadata.title: We Will Call You | Ep 4: Skills Matchmaker | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: AI for recruiting - replace your HR with artificial lack of intelligence.

all_paragraphs: The voice from the loudspeakers soothed Domnall’s ego, somewhat bruised by events of the last few months. The voice in the back of his head suggested, in turn, that the number of people who had heard exactly the same words probably counts in thousands.
“Thank you,” Domnall answered instinctively. Just in time, he remembered to smile, and he curled his lips ever so slightly.
“I have the last question,” said the lady on the screen.

Domnall found it hard to imagine anyone equally emotionally transparent to him. Neither pretty nor ugly, neither stupid nor smart, the woman was so matter-of-fact and easy-going at the same time, so balanced between distance and enthusiasm, and so full of unsurpassed perfection that somewhere in all this there was no space left for personality.
“Could you please describe the project from your previous work that you are the proudest of and explain how the project added significant value to the company?”

Domnall stiffened. Unfortunately, he didn’t stay in the company long enough to evaluate the results of the project, of which he was the proudest. For a moment, he was tempted to remind the authors of this riddle that project satisfaction and added value do not always have to go hand in hand, but he gave it a rest. Something else worried him; until now all questions were indistinguishable from cross-word definitions with a question mark added. Why suddenly this open form?
His hesitation had to be noticed because the woman encouraged him once again:
“If confidentiality clauses prohibit you from talking about this project, please tell me about one that you can.”

“The agreement that I signed on leaving was mainly a long and detailed list of things I mustn’t do,” Domnall focused so much on breaking the embarrassing silence that he put his foot in it. “But most of them ensured I would not express negative opinions about the company in any form,” he added and immediately reprimanded himself in his thoughts. He was babbling again instead of going to the merits. The recruiter warned him; the message shall be short, clear and to the point! He pulled himself together. “The situation was as follows; to reduce costs, the company terminated the expensive logistics management system, but unfortunately, they did it before its cheaper replacement was implemented.”
No, that didn’t sound good either. Such wording not only puts Domnall at risk of a meeting with his former employer’s lawyers but also his interlocutor could categorize him as a malcontent.
“What an interesting project,” the woman interrupted unexpectedly. Her voice was as friendly as before. “Why do you think the situation was as follows?”
Domnall was dumbfounded. Did he mishear? This question did not make sense!

“My settlement agreement explicitly prohibits me from expressing my opinion about the reasons for the situation my company found itself in,” he answered, just to say something, wondering whether the woman, in her boundless perfection, allows any error reports.
“So you don’t have an opinion on that?”

“Let’s assume I don’t have one,” Domnall muttered, completely forgetting to smile. The next sentences he spoke slowly, loudly and clearly. “Returning to the project, the obstacles were: information chaos, the multitude of data sources, and quality of data. Actions that I took — I designed and prepared a prototype of a substitute system. I automated the processing and cleaning of data in relational databases. Where possible, I added predictive elements using various python machine learning libraries.”
The woman was silent a bit longer than usual.
“I didn’t notice how this project significantly added to the company’s value” she complained. “Could you rephrase that, please?”

“I quit my job looking for new opportunities and challenges too soon to know exact results, but if they implemented my system, they could significantly minimize the chaos that costs the company millions of dollars a year.”

“Thank you very much. That was the last question.” If the woman wiped a smile from her lips, her face would express absolute nothing. “Analyzing your statements, I conclude that you match fourteen out of eighteen required skills. I didn’t notice you have experience with SQL, pandas and scikit-learn libraries, and you lack the ability to communicate opinions precisely.”

“Scikit-learn is one of the python packages!” Domnall snorted. “I used it, as well as the Keras library, and PyTorch. I don’t even mention pandas, as I don’t mention that I use the keyboard! Besides, SQL is a standard for handling the relational databases I did mention. As for communication, it’s difficult to demand my definite opinion, if it is legally forbidden for me to express one!” he burst out and added, “You can’t evaluate me based solely on keywords!”

“Statements given after the end of the question session are not taken into account,” said the invariably warm voice of the interviewing program — the masterpiece of millions of tiny equations optimizing it for professionalism. “With a score of fourteen points, you are in the sixth-ten of candidates. We will call you.”
Episode 6: Passionate, more passionate, hired!

Domnall is a brilliant guy. However, job-seeking is long-term entertainment, and will probably take him a while. Especially that job interviews don’t happen every day. In the meantime, you may consider reading about other (equally brilliant) characters in our #Pharmacon sociological thriller.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Publishing authors, former scientists, current entrepreneurs. Topics: (popular) science, pop-culture, new technologies, and sociology.
